step.context: \textbf{Right or wrong? } \text{If }f(x) = \dfrac{g(x)}{h(x)}, \\ \text{then}\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\text{ is given by the following.}
step.reason: \text{When differentiating a function of the form}\\ \qquad f(x) = \dfrac{g(x)}{h(x)} \\ \text{you need to use the }\textbf{Quotient Rule}.\\ \qquad \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = \dfrac{h(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x) - g(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}h(x)}{h(x)^2}

step.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Function} & \text{Derivative} \\ \hline g(x) = \sin (ax + b) & g'(x) = \cos (ax + b) \\ \hline h(x) = \cos (cx + d) & h'(x) = -\sin (cx + d) \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \begin{align} &\therefore \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = \dfrac{h(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x) - g(x)\cdot\frac{d}{dx}h(x)}{h(x)^2}\\ &= \dfrac{\cos(ax+b)\cdot\cos(cx+d) + \cos(ax+b)\cdot\sin(cx+d)}{\cos^2(cx+d)} \\ &= \dfrac{\cos (ax + b)\cdot [1 + \tan (cx+d)]}{\cos (cx + d)} \end{align}
step.reason: \text{Quotient rule was required to find }f'(x). \\ \text{But Chain Rule was required to find the}\\ g'(x)\text{ and }h'(x)\text{ that are needed in }f'(x).
